tool.name: OSMGPFileLoader

param.name: in_osmFile
param.dialogReference: The name and the location of the OSM file. Most commonly the xml file will have ".osm" as the file extension.
param.pythonReference: The name and the location of the OSM file.

param.name: in_conserveMemory
param.dialogReference:
This parameter determine where the node information is store while constructing the geometry for the polyline features in the geodatabase.

  • CONSERVE_MEMORY: Does not store the node information in memory but fetches the node geometries from the geodatabase directly. This is the default (checked) option.

  • DO_NOT_CONSERVE_MEMORY: Stores the node information during the polyline geometry construction in memory. The more linear features exist in the planet file the more memory is required on the machine. As a rule of thumb do not use this option if the size of your planet file is larger than the amount of RAM on the machine. This is the unchecked option.
param.pythonReference:
This parameter determine where the node information is store while constructing the geometry for the polyline features in the geodatabase.

  • CONSERVE_MEMORY: Does not store the node information in memory but fetches the node geometries from the geodatabase directly. This is the default (checked) option.

  • DO_NOT_CONSERVE_MEMORY: Stores the node information during the polyline geometry construction in memory. The more linear features exist in the planet file the more memory is required on the machine. As a rule of thumb do not use this option if the size of your planet file is larger than the amount of RAM on the machine. This is the unchecked option.

param.name: out_targetdataset
param.dialogReference: The name of the feature dataset into which the OSM data will be downloaded. The target workspace should either be a file geodatabase or an enterprise (SDE) geodatabase.
param.pythonReference: The name of the feature dataset into which the OSM data will be downloaded. The target workspace should either be a file geodatabase or an enterprise (SDE) geodatabase.

param.name: out_osmPoints
param.dialogReference: Feature class containing the translated OSM node features.
param.pythonReference: Feature class containing the translated OSM node features.

param.name: out_osmLines
param.dialogReference: Feature class containing the translated OSM way features if they are considered linear.
param.pythonReference: Feature class containing the translated OSM way features if they are considered linear.

param.name: out_osmPolygons
param.dialogReference: Feature class containing the translated OSM way features if they are considered polygonal.
param.pythonReference: Feature class containing the translated OSM way features if they are considered polygonal.

tool.summary: This tool allows the user to load stand alone OpenStreetMap (OSM) xml files as in *.osm or planet files.
tool.usage:
• Vector data from OSM (OpenStreetMap) is downloaded locally and translated into the appropriate geometry:

    • Nodes are translated into points

    • Ways are either translated into lines or polygons. Closed ways are candidates for polygonal features and ways that contain the key/value pair of 'area=yes'.

  • Relations are stored in a table _osm_relation in the specified workspace.

  • Changes of local edits are recorded in a table called _osm_revision. This table stores the upload status as well and it is used in resolving upload conflicts.

  • Remember to place proper attribution when using the data in projects. To learn more about the attribution guidelines, please refer to the OpenStreetMap website.

scriptExample.title: Load OSM File Sample (Python)
scriptExample.para: This Python window sample demonstrates how to load a stand-alone OSM file and store it as a feature dataset inside a geodatabase.
scriptExample.code:
# import the system modules import arcpy from arcpy import env
# load the OpenStreetMap specific toolbox arcpy.ImportToolbox(r'd:\projects\OSMEditor\WheelChairMap\OpenStreetMap Toolbox.tbx')
# set the workspace environment env.workspace = r'd:\projects\OSMEditor\WheelChairMap\defaultstorage.gdb'
# request the data from the OSM server and store it in the target feature dataset arcpy.OSMGPDownload_osmtools(r'http://www.openstreetmap.org', '9.1562 48.8078 9.1929 48.8278', 'DO_NOT_INCLUDE_REFERENCES', r'stuttgart', r'stuttgart\stuttgart_osm_pt', r'stuttgart\stuttgart_osm_ln', r'stuttgart\stuttgart_osm_ply')

scriptExample.title: Load OSM File Sample 2 (Python)
scriptExample.code:
# import the system modules import arcpy from arcpy import env
# load the OpenStreetMap specific toolbox arcpy.ImportToolbox(r'd:\projects\OSMEditor\WheelChairMap\OpenStreetMap Toolbox.tbx')
# set the workspace environment env.workspace = r'd:\projects\OSMEditor\WheelChairMap\defaultstorage.gdb'
# define a base name for the download inputName = 'stuttgart'
# define the names for the feature dataset and the feature classes validatedTableName = arcpy.ValidateTableName(inputName, env.workspace) nameOfTargetDataset = arcpy.os.path.join(arcpy.env.workspace, validatedTableName)
nameOfPointFeatureClass = arcpy.os.path.join(env.workspace, validatedTableName, validatedTableName + r'_osm_pt') nameOfLineFeatureClass = arcpy.os.path.join(env.workspace, validatedTableName, validatedTableName + r'_osm_ln') nameOfPolygonFeatureClass = arcpy.os.path.join(env.workspace, validatedTableName, validatedTableName + r'_osm_ply')
# load the stand-alone OSM file and store it in the target feature dataset arcpy.OSMGPFileLoader_osmtools(r'c:\temp\map.osm', 'CONSERVE_MEMORY', nameOfTargetDataset, nameOfPointFeatureClass, nameOfLineFeatureClass, nameOfPolygonFeatureClass)

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This tool allows the user to load stand alone OpenStreetMap (OSM) xml files as in *.osm or planet files.
This tool allows the user to load stand alone OpenStreetMap (OSM) xml files as in *.osm or planet files.
